In der Kürze liegt die Würze - dieser altbekannte Spruch trifft bei The Lion's Song absolut ins Schwarze!

45 Minuten habe ich für die erste, kostenlose Episode benötigt und schon nach diesem kurzen Zeitfenster habe ich Lust, das Spiel noch einmal mit anderen Entscheidungen auszuprobieren. Und noch viel neugieriger bin ich auf die weiteren Episoden.

Die Grafik wirkt auf den ersten Blick sicher etwas einfach, passt aber hervorragend zur Atmosphäre des Spiels. Die Art und Weise, wie die Bedeutung von Träumen in das Spiel eingewoben ist und wie authentisch die Komposition des Musikstücks daherkommt, ist wirklich beeindruckend.

Fans von Visual Novels und Adventures können hier nichts falsch machen, so lange man nicht zu große Erwartungen an die Spielzeit hat!

Wilma, der Hauptcharakter, bietet einen großen Einblick in ihr inneres Gefühlsleben, sodass zumindest mir nichts anderes übrig blieb als dasselbe zu fühlen. 24330510.review: When I saw the game for the first time I though that it was going to be something like Broken Sword which is an amazing game but, The Lion Song actually differs from it in certain ways. It is just a static point and click game, there is not a character to move or other buttons to press, you only need the mouse. The game is pretty short, well, its first episode, as the other episodes are released I think that it will acquire a good game length. The major aspects from the game remain on its story and its music, the story is easy to understand but charming and can be analized from different perspectives, the music is beautiful and plays a main role in the story. Finally the replay value is good as there are many secrets that involve the plot and you will need to play again in order to find them all. In conclusion it is an excellent game, I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a charming story or, to the point and click games fans.

24322952.review:
(Presa dal mio video su Youtube)
La musica classica. A chi non piace? Che tu sia un metallaro o un fan della musica house, dubstep trap insomma ci sarà sempre quel pezzo di Mozart, Bethoveen o anche di Hans Zimmer. Vi basterà pensare al componimento ''Up is down'' di quest'ultimo per farvi un idea su quanto le mie parole siano vere.
Ebbene, oggi popolo di Youtube, andrò a parlare di un gioco, uscito di recente, che riporta proprio questo tema, o almeno nel suo primo episodio.
The Lion's song.
Questo gioco si presenta come un punta e clicca old style, vi ricordate The Monkey Island o Syberia?
In questo gioco impersonerete Wilma, una compositrice che a quanto pare ''perde'' la sua creatività e decide su consiglio del suo professore di andare sulle alpi in una baita per cercare la sua musa e finire la sua ultima composizione, che porterà in una sala di Vienna.
Il gioco non propone una vera grafica come in altri giochi del genere del calibro di Syberia o The walking Dead, ma bensi' propone una pixel art con varie animazioni.
La musica e' ben fatta e anche i personaggi sono anche ben rappresentati, nonostante manchi la componente recitativa di questi ultimi.
Insomma, non c'è molto da dire, possso solo invitarvi a provarlo in quanto troverete il primo episodio gratis su steam (Link in descrizione) mentre per gli altri episodi anche se non sono ancora usciti ci vorrà un Season Pass ma credetemi che dopo aver giocato il primo episodio la voglia di continuare questo viaggio artistico a Vienna sarà quasi come un Must Do.

24310773.review:
The first episode is free, and since each episode from the rest of the game (paid via season pass) will be self-contained, the free download is not in any way a tactful teaser - it is a short, self-contained story that is interesting and well-told.

Basically, the game operates in a similar manner to a point-and-click adventure game, though it is more 'on-rails' than a traditional P&C game. The graphical style is also quite nice, though I could understand if it alienated some gamers.

The bottom line is this: It's free, so try it out - this is how an episodic game should be marketed, and the season pass is perfectly priced!

24291064.review:
[h1]The Lion’s Song[/h1] est une série d’épisodes indépendants point and click ayant pour toile de fond l’Autriche du début du 20e siècle. 
Une sorte de visual novel intéractive dans laquelle on dirige la charmante Wilma, une artiste prometteuse qui doit écrire une pièce mais qui ne trouve pas l’inspiration. 
Ajoutez à cela une relation amoureuse désirée avec son maitre de musique et vous obtenez une histoire courte (gratuite) mais ô combien charmante. 

Le premier épisode de cette série, nommé sobrement Silence, est disponible gratuitement sur Steam. 
[u]Un bon moyen de le tester et de vous faire une idée avant, qui sait, de goûter à l’intégralité de la série.[/u]
[b]The Lion's Song sera disponible dans un premier temps sur PC, suivi plus tard cette année par des versions iOS et Android. Le Season Pass est désormais disponible pour 9.99 €. Les épisodes individuels seront également disponibles, au prix de 3.99 € chacun.[/b]

Beautiful, artful, filled with scenery and live, a wonderful experience. 

This is an exzellent example of a well paced evolution of a digital narrative. It's more like a living, slightly interactive visual novel than a game. After finishing it, I wanted to replay it, just to revisit the well drawn sceneries and have a new chance for other conversations, but I will do that on my iPad, when it is released on mobile too.

24269796.review:
A short game about the world of music, but you come out of it with so much more than you could have expected.

This game popped up on my recommended list and at first I went straight past it, but when it came up again I decided to check it out and since it was free I had nothing to lose. The Lion’s Song: Episode 1 is a unique and creative piece of art which dwells deeper than the struggles of a composer. Instead we’re drawn into a character which we are so easily able to relate to because of the issues she deals with. 

In Ep.1 you play as Wilma, a young upcoming musician who is struggling to not only find motivation but also a sense of identity. The unique adaptation on how she finds motivation to write her latest piece is wonderfully written and created that is has so much more depth than what I expected from a Point & Click game.

This short Ep. is definitely worth checking out, especially since the first Episode is free. The art style and the music will draw you in straight away but the depth of the story will keep you in till the end. I’m excited to see how the developers take on the next three episodes, and how the story unfolds from here. 

7/10

24263006.review:
Análisis fácil y rápido: [b]ES GRATIS[/b], pruébalo. A que esperas.

Análisis largo:

Este proyecto de Mi'pu'mi Games es sin duda un ejemplo claro de jugabilidad sencilla (es un point n' click) acompañado de una soberbia línea narrativa que siempre te mantiene en vilo, impaciente y ansioso por saber que es lo que ocurrirá despues de cada decisión. El apartado sonoro y musica realizado por Dynamedion es espectacular. Muy buena calidad y ambientación y una melodías que penetran profundamente en la cabeza, dibujandote de manera sutil una armonía final. Respecto a la apartado jugable, podrían estar presentes algunos elementos más cercanos al género de puzzlesque completementarían perfectamente con las decisiones que se pueden tomar en los dialogos y, en efecto, con el generó en sí del juego.

¿Artísicamente? Conmovedor, inesperado y simple a la vez que elaborado y bien trabajado. No te dejes engañar por los píxeles, no te imaginas lo bien que pueden llegar a contar una historia sin ser un juego de calidad triple A.

Todo sea dicho, es una buena propuesta si te eres asiduo a este venerado género, aunque en alguna ocasion te dejará más vacío que satisfecho. Por otro lado, si no eres de los que aprecia de manera devota este modo de juego, puedes probarlo, podría sorprenderte la calidad que posee, al fin y al cabo, el primer episodio es gratuito.

Por mi parte, sin ser muy fan de este género, espero impaciente el siguiente episodio, con el que me haré cuando mis recursos me lo permitan.

24262863.review:
As someone who does play violin, but does not write music, I found this episode really interesting. In episode 1, you play Wilma, a violinist who has been named more or less a prodigy under her teacher. She must finish her composition, but Wilma gets stressed, the silence doesn't stay long enough, and everything seems to be refusing the passage of creativity.

   The Lion's Song doesn't require you knowing (or being able to play) an instrument, just to understand the predicament the character is in. While this game may be simple, it does well with how your interactions affect the ending. Each decision is subtle, whether it affects dialogue, Wilma, or the storyline. The music plays on the situation, and easily affects the player based on what brought it on.

   Don't let the art style drive you away, The Lion's Song: Silence is worth playing (it is free after all!). I do see some flaws but it does not take anything away nor ruin the experience. I will certainly wait for future episodes and see how each character tackles their respective mediums and how struggling with creativity, human interactions, and inspiration personally affects each character.

(Chapters 2-3 reviews coming soon)

24256699.review:
8 COISAS QUE ME ATRAIRAM NO JOGO (e que espero atrair você também):

1- O jogo é fluído e dinâmico, existe todo um contexto onde querendo ou não o jogador precisa se envolver para tomar as decisões da personagem, e isso é muito bom.
2- O jogo é simples e ao mesmo tempo não perde a qualidade e não faz com que o jogador que o comprou (mesmo que de graça) perca a vontade de jogá-lo.
3- A arte em pixels feita por Natascha Pittauer e as animações em gif de Tobias Mayr são lindas e delicadas como a personagem do jogo.
4- A história. São poucas vezes que vemos jogos com o contexto musical, ainda mais se tratando de uma compositora em busca de inspiração. Isso é novo para mim. A ambientação na Áustria e Viena faz quem joga sentir-se nestes lugares.
5- A TRILHA SONORA. Você joga e ajuda Vilma a se inspirar em sua nova composição e o objetivo final é fazer com que ela termine e toque no tão esperado concerto, ou seja, você joga esperando ouvir o que ela criará.
6- O jogo é dividido em 4 capítulos: Silêncio, Antologia, Derivação e Encerramento. Se você notar bem perceberá que os nomes destes capítulos são nada mais do que as fases de um concerto do início ao fim. 
7- Ele é curto e tão fluído que em poucos minutos você termina o primeiro capítulo. 
8- Já se perguntou porque o jogo se passa na Aústria? Sim, ele foi produzido lá (em Hollandstraße), os produtores são alemães e austríacos e isso explica toda a descrição poética do lugar feita por Vilma, Leon e outros personagens.

Traduzindo em miúdos você vivencia o vazio criativo de quem trabalha com música e de quem assim como todos nós tem um prazo a cumprir e milhares de coisas que podem atrapalhar a concentração. O jogo faz o jogador se interessar por música clássica (mesmo que por poucos instantes). 

* O único defeito creio eu que muitos também devem ter dito é que a versão gratuita libera apenas o primeiro capítulo do jogo "Silence" que é onde nos é apresentada a personagem Vilma e sua mudança para a casa nos alpes austríacos. Após terminar este capítulo é preciso que o jogador compre o Season Pass (um DLC que irá liberar para a próxima fase "Derivation") por R$ 38,99.  

Obrigada por ler!
Espero ter explicado um pouco do conteúdo do jogo :D
Um abraço!

Amanda S.

24243047.review:
tl;dr: Not one of the best point-and-click that I've ever play at all, mostly a driven story with no much interaction. 
Give a try if you like the genre.

Starting with the pro:
I like really much the pixelated graphic and the (not so new) game mechanic of the "only one question/response" which, sadly, had none or very little impact on the story if not only for unlock some archievements... for now. 

Too bad there are so many important things that I found poorly made. The most awful is the music... don't get me wrong, it's not so bad BUT we're playing a game where the main character is a talented musician (very promising from what we know from the story) and her composition is what gives the name to the series so why is it so disappointing?  
The plot also feel rushed and even if Wanda is a nice character per sé I don't feel touched by her or her story, too many events in so little time and... 
*URGH* I HATE so much the impossibility to explore the surrounding areas. We had... 5 total locations whom 3 barely interactive? Ok, I can understand that the makers want so badly drive the attention to the story and this isn't even the first game where the protagonist can't move if not for interact with few object but I had the feeling to play her part from a grave, under 7 feet of fresh mold, with tied hands too. Did I really make some difference in her story? I think not and I felt bored for the most time.

I've so many mixed feelings about recommend this game, it's free and worth a try. Think that's similar to read a book and you will be less disappointed. Don't *DON'T* link it as a point-and-click game, no please, really don't, it's a different kind of game and I'm deadly serious about.

Yeah, maybe I'm too harsh on judgement but the first episode of a series is like a business card and this one is printed in comic sans.

The Lions Song... Gerade beendet und schon lust auf das 2te Kapitel.

The Lions Song ist ein Point & Click Adventure gepaart mit einer Liebevollen Story und Wundervollen Musik.
Ist zwar nicht für jeden was dabei, aber da die erste Episode Kostenlos ist, kann man sich das mal anschauen. Auch wenn sie gerade mal 45 minuten gedauerst hat ist die erste Episode einfach Toll.

Wir Spielen Wilma, eine Musikstudenten aus Wien. Sie soll in die Alpen gehen um dort ihre Komposition vollenden.
Vor ort wird sie immerwieder von Geräuschen und einem Unwetter Gestört, doch eine Schicksalhafte Begegnung bringt Licht ins Dunkel.

[b][u]Grafik[/u][/b] Die Gesammte Grafik besteht aus einem abgestimmten Pixelstil mit ein wenigen Dunklen Farben, die Perfekt zur Stimmung des Spiels passen.

[b][u]INFO:[/u][/b] Ich will für dieses Spiel keine Riesige Review schreiben, weil ja noch weitere Episoden erscheinen. Dazu seht darüber hinweg, wenn ich mich wiederhole oder etwas vergesse, ich bin kein Profi und mache das nur aus Spaß.

24210740.review:
[h1]Artistico y genial¡ [/h1] 

Pocos juegos como The Lion's Song logran ser tan humanos, los personajes se sienten reales, melancolicos y sin los esteriotipos clasicos de los videojuegos, tienen varias aspiraciones, se confunden, hasta sienten hambre y se siente que quien lo escribio sentia lo mismo, y giran entorno a las inspiraciones artisticas de los personajes. 

El primer episodio se centra en componer una melodia (lo resumo para no arruinar la experiencia) y todo influye en ella; una conversación, un molesto ruido, una pausa, como sucede cuando uno mismo trata de crear o componer, y lo transmite a la perfección, y no abusa de los montajes de pelicula donde el protagonista canta y se desplaza saltando en su habitación, aqui todo avanza sutilmente.

Y tienes el primer capitulo GRATIS, debes probarlo, y si logra llegarte el mensaje que transmite, y su visión artistica que pocos entienden, recomiendo comprar el pase de temporada, si no, simplemente puedes seguir adelante sin haber gastado dinero.

24201481.review: It reminded me of Firewatch without the good graphics, interesting storyline, or puzzles; where the sex of the protagonist is reversed. It is rudimentary in nature and the game requires a basal knowledge of problem solving skills. As a "point-and-click" story it offers very little back-story or emotional investment. It becomes overly simplistic to understand how the game operates and essentially it becomes a chore. The game relies on music to bend the heartstrings yet it repeats the same tired notes over and over in hopes to create a sense of nostalgia that never has time to develop. The main character is an annoyingly neurotic musician that we are supposed to find a kinship for yet she barely reveals any aspect of soul or personal depth. One might argue that the goal of the game is introspection and that the character is a blank slate to be impressed upon. Unfortunately there are precious few opportunities to do so. The choices (unlike life in actuality) are very clear with black and white consequences. All of this seems overly analytical for a game that is about as solid as chaff in the wind.

[use Google Translator, foreigners]

Sem querer desmerecer o esforço da galera por trás disto (pois todo jogo, péssimo ou ótimo, dá trabalho para fazer), mas o produto não vale o preço previsto. Se, em liquidações, Psychonauts é vendido a menos de dois reais (R$) e The Witcher's a menos de 10 (dando exemplos aleatórios), isso deveria ser vendido a centavos, então.
[B]Não há nada aqui[/b]. Sem díalogos importantes, sem puzzles, sem escolhas (de verdade), sem exploração... sem nenhuma vertente que o gênero point'n'click/adventure disponibiliza. Não há uma linha de raciocínio a ser seguida. Você apenas espera os dias seguirem se certificando que todos os hotspots foram clicados. O bacaninha fica nas passagens que a personagem se inspira para compor, mas só se você tiver afinidade com estudos musicais ou artes, em geral.

Resumindo, não é um jogo que você deva gastar dinheiro. Obtenha apenas se for grátis.

24192646.review: Une jeune compositrice au succès prometteur, secrètement amoureuse de son professeur qui la pousse vers le succès. La pression est telle que le syndrome de la page, pour sa nouvelle composition pour le concert qui doit l’amener à la gloire, la frappe. Envoyé par son professeur dans une cabane isolée en pleine montagne, la jeune femme devra faire taire le bruit ambiant pour entendre sa nouvelle symphonie étant donné que le secret de la musique réside dans l’art de gérer le silence. Non linéaire, plusieurs choix s’offriront à vous pour composer votre chef d’œuvre. Ce premier épisode commence la saga très fort, où nous suivrons tour à tour, une compositrice, un peintre et une mathématicienne et où les choix réalisés auront un impact sur les épisodes suivants. Essayer le jeu, le premier épisode est en accès gratuit.

24190661.review:
The Lion's Song Episode 1 - Silence est une sorte de visual novel intéractive dans laquelle on dirige la charmante Wilma, une artiste prometteuse qui doit écrire une pièce mais qui ne trouve pas l'inspiration. Ajoutez à cela une relation amoureuse désirée avec son maitre de musique et vous obtenez une histoire courte mais ô combien charmante dans laquelle on va devoir trouver des solutions au manque d'inspiration de Wilma par différents biais.

The Lion's Song Episode 1 - Silenceest disponible gratuitement sur Steam avec la possibilité d'acheter un season pack à 9.99€ qui nous permettra de découvrir 3 autres histoires avec de nouveaux protagonistes. Cet épisode se termine en environ 30-40 minutes pour peu que l'on prenne la peine de tout lire et d'essayer de faire les bons choix afin que Wilma puisse connaitre le succès qu'elle mérite. N'attendez donc pas un jeu qui dure des heures même si on a la possibilité de le refaire plusieurs fois afin d'avoir des fins différentes. Cela nous permettra également de débloquer des achievements plutôt sympathiques pour la plupart.

On ne contrôle pas vraiment Wilma mais on peut agir avec différents éléments du décor ou alors directement avec d'autres personnages. Le jeu nous mets parfois sur la voie histoire que l'on puisse trouver les différentes sources d'inspiration de Wilma. Pour peu que l'on soit un brin curieux, on a également la possibilité d'en savoir plus sur notre professeur aimé. Sans vouloir gâcher la surprise, certains de nos choix feront évoluer l'histoire de façon positive ou négative. Wilma a également une fâcheuse tendance à faire des cauchemars singuliers mais qui apportent énormément au bout d'histoire de ce premier épisode.

Au final, The Lion's Song Episode 1 - Silence est une vraiment un jeu à part! On commence le jeu sans trop d'espoir mais on s'accroche très vite à l'ambiance et au doux rêve de Wilma. Je vous invite d'ailleurs à regarder la présentation des développeurs à la fin du jeu que je trouve excellente et originale! Je suis tombé complètement sous le charme de ce premier épisode et je vais m'empresser d'acheter la saison complète!

24190114.review:
Ein wunderbar poetisches Spiel, aber wahrscheinlich nicht für jedermann geeignet!

Ich habe die erste Episode gerade beendet und bin ziemlich begeistert:
Der Grafikstil ist pixelig aber stimmig. Die nur aus wenig Farben bestehende Coloration passt einfach nur genial zur Handlung, die in Österreich im frühen 20. Jahrhundert spielt.
Dazu kommt eine ganz athmosphärische Vertonung, die nur auf Geräusche und Musik setzt und auf gesprochene Sprache völlig verzichtet, was wie ich finde auch genau richtig ist.

Das Spielprinzip ist einfach, quasi eine Visual Novel mit Point and Click Momenten, wobei die Entscheidungen, die man treffen kann, wenig Einfluss auf die Handlung zu nehmen scheinen. (Ob diese nicht doch noch Bedeutung haben werden, weiß man natürlich erst, wenn auch die anderen Episoden erschienen sind.)

Die erste Episode ist relativ kurz (dafür aber auch völlig kostenlos!) und sollte man wohl auch lieber in einem Rutsch durchspielen. Zwischendrin eine Pause zu machen, würde das Erlebnis irgendwie kaputt machen, finde ich.

Ich bin schon sehr neugierig auf die nächsten Folgen, ob es in ihnen auch um Kreativität und Inspiration gehen wird und ob es eine Verbindung zwischen ihnen geben wird. Den Season-Pass hab ich jedenfalls sofort gekauft, schon allein, damit die Entwickler wissen, dass ich auf den Rest der Geschichte wirklich Wert lege!

24189828.review:
*Short personal summary of my experience with "The Lion's Song: Episode 1- Silence" as well as a fleshed out review*

Where to begin...
"The Lion's Song: Episode 1" has already intrigued me. With a short but effective narrative and with a beautifully paced arch, it is truly a great experience. Now, this is not a long game (or episode of a game). I managed to complete "Episode 1- Silence" in about fourty minutes. But in those fourty minutes...I felt like I was somewhere else. That I really was the main character (Wilma). That I really struggled alongside her with love, the composition of the piece. Truly magical. Her parents sends her away to Vienna, and it feels like they send me away. And her brother Otto, my brother Otto, is also sent away several years (I presume, don't take my word for it) later on the same train. And this is where the story begins.

Plot: 9,5/10
You play as a young girl named Wilma, an up and coming musician and composer who is currently learning from a man named Arthur in Vienna, Austria. Arthur requests a meeting with you to explain that he wants her to create a new piece; and make it the best she has ever composed. Wilma is stunned. "How am I supposed to write a piece when there is so much distractions around me" she asks. Arthur offers his cabin in the Alps as a refuge from Vienna. He sends her there the next day, and when she arrives, Wilma is filled with determination. She is going to compose her best piece yet.

A relativeley simple, yet elegant story. While some characters don't feel fleshed out enough (Arthur, her mom and dad and her little brother, Otto) the truth is they don't have to be. What is there is enough to keep the story moving forward and keep it intriguing all the way to the end. 

Estethics (graphics in basic english): 10/10
I was first surprised by the design choice of making the entire game pixelated and in 2D. But it works so well. I would've probably not liked if this was a 3D game, it feels more like an indie title. So, great choice there by the developers. It suits the game perfectly.

Gameplay: 8/10
"The Lion's Song" is a point-and-click game. Now that surprised me, but in a good way. Point-and-click games have always been hit or miss for me. Either they work perfectly, or they fail miserably. But in this, "The Lion's Song" suceeds. It fits the story so well. Finding inspiration in your surroundings, blocking out distracting noises, choosing to pick up the phone or not. It just works. A problem is that there are very few hints in the game, so you have to find out for yourself how to make the piece. But when you do, it's oh so satsifying.

Final verdict: A strong 9/10
"The Lion's Song: Episode 1- Silence" is a breath of fresh air in a world populated by FPS:s. With a simple yet effective pixelated art style and a beautiful and elegant story, and with gameplay that genuinly suits the story it is trying to tell, "The Lion's Song" caught me offguard. I was not prepared to enjoy the game as much as I did. I can't wait for the next episode to come out, "Episode 2: Anthology" which follows an artist with a destiny...

Try it. It will not dissapoint you.

24189299.review:
[b]Well done, devs, well done![/b] 
I just finished Episode 1 and I'm aleady certain that I will be playing the following ones.

+ Great sounddesign that sets the mood just right.
   The hustle and bustle of Vienna? Done. Wind rustling through the trees? Done. A rainy and stormy day? Done. Wilma can't concentrate on the melody in her head because there are too many distracting sounds? Done. Wait, even that one was on point? Wonderful.
+ Stunning pixelart. 
   Just look at the screenshots! Yeah!
+ Great OST. 
   Perfect if you just want to sit back, relax and play a nice game.
+ Interesting and original story and setting.
   I have never seen anything like it. And let me tell you, I've played many, many games in my time.
+ Flawless German translation. 
   Propably because the devs are from Vienna themselves...oh well.

~ The decisions you make feel rather insignificant and some of the dialogue options are extremely similar. 
   To me personally, this just adds to the realism and immersion since you don't exactly make world-changing decisions in your everyday life either, but I could imagine that some players might be annoyed by this.
~ The first episode was really short. 
   This isn't exactly a negative point for me either, since it was free and the following ones might be longer when they come out. But even if they aren't, four episodes with about 30-50 minutes of quality playtime each are definitely worth 10 bucks.

So, in conclusion: 
Try it for yourself! It's fun! It's relaxing! And - best of all - it's free!

[i](And if you like it, buy it and support indie devs that dare to make original content!)[/i]

----------
A more in-depth review will propably follow as soon as further episodes are released.

24186599.review:
Episode 1/4

Pros:
[list]
[*]Free (Therefore try it - what do you have to loose?!)
[*]Wonderful Soundtrack!
[*]Nice pixelart (if you can stand pixelart)
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Super short: Episode 1 just takes about 30 minutes
[*]No voiced character
[*]Choices feel super meaningless. They likely built up for later episodes but you will have to buy the season package and play all episodes to see for yourself if your choices had any impact on the outcome.
[*]Episode 1 feels like a setup episode and therefore like a demo - it is free, therefore likely it was intented that way. The story starts with the character of episode 2 but you will never face him again in episode 1, therefore it is completly unecessary for you to see this scene yet. However, it feels like the writing should foreshadow what is to come in episode 2.
[*]The pixelhunt puzzles have a great idea behind them: You always look for what is currently struggling the character and it is incorporated in what your character does. However, it is pretty obvious what to do at every point in the game, therefore you just click your way through the episode and suddenly everything is over. It is more like a short narrated story of 20-30 minutes than a real game.
[*]The story falls a bit flat so far. Not much happens and actually the whole episode you face a single problem: "Noises" and your whole task is to find those noises. There are sequences between this minigame but the game simply lacks anything you really want.
[*]The pixel-style font is sometimes difficult to read and the emphasis effect on some of the words indicates some special importance of them - I could not find what they tried to hint me.
[/list]

Overall: Episode 1 is free and plays like a demo. Mi'pu'mi Games clearly showed that they are able to built a narrative telltale-style game (or "life is strange"-style if you wish). What really is missing are more important decisions. Decisions which are hard for you as a player to take because it feels like one of the choices has any meaning. Currently there were only one choice where I really had this feeling and this is only one of the "big" choices listed at the end-screen which really delivered a glimpse of character definition or developement. One of those choices deals with: "What does the character really want". A game about that much struggle should also make me as a player struggle. In the end of the episode I want to feel success when the character succeeds or I want to feel the sadness or desparation if the character is sad or desparate.

24177185.review:
免费的体验，舒缓的音乐，复古的画风，没有理由不把第一次评论献给它。

这样一种画风，让我想起了高中时候作为文艺委员在教室黑板上作画的情形。布满粉笔灰的黑板，就像游戏中的背景（如掉色一般）。班主任从不给我买水粉颜料，我也就只好拿着粉笔作画。黄色粉笔、白色粉笔、红色粉笔、绿色粉笔和紫色粉笔，再加点水和手纸，孤军奋战两天，就能大致画出像游戏那样的图画。因此当我玩这个游戏时，就有满满的回忆感和浓浓的温情。

游戏中的像素画，需要大量采用留白手法。比如游戏展示的第三幅图，右边出现的男人轮廓就是通过留白手法表现的。不一而足。

游戏的另一个亮点是背景音乐，值得玩家细细品味。

狮之歌第一章：寂静 免费放出啦！

20世纪初维亚纳的一个才华横溢年轻漂亮的小提琴家wilma，完成了一曲惊艳的作品。她的导师arthur认为她的作品是一种全新的形式，希望她能做出更棒的作品，但wilma感到新曲的创作碰到巨大的压力，arthur建议她前往阿尔卑斯山一个与世隔绝的小木屋去寻找创作灵感。[spoiler]（反正秘密情人嘛，教授总有个分基地的。）[/spoiler]

到了小木屋后，wilma看到包里有一封信，教授为她专门筹备一场演奏会，时间在一周后。请来了那谁那谁那谁反正都是因为她作品的惊艳而加盟的音乐人，只有一周的时间创作，wilma顿时感觉亚历山大。而这时她接到了一个自称是leo的客栈老板电话，他只是想尝试一下这个新奇的装置跟数百英里之外的人聊聊天……

接下来wilma何去何从？wilma顶着巨大的压力，在这个与世隔绝的地方如何获得新作的灵感？

音乐好评，气氛好评，故事好评，推荐一玩。

24173534.review:
When I first came across the Lion’s Song it was purely at random, but when my gaze fell upon some of the screenshots from the game, I quickly added it onto my wishlist and waited patiently for its release, until today. 

The Lion’s Song, produced by the Austrian studio Mi'pu'mi Games and whose moto is “Great games don’t have to be big” (and I couldn’t agree more), is an episodic, point & click series that takes place during the early 20th century. In the first episode of The Lion’s Song we follow Wilma, an up and coming violinist who is under a lot of pressure to finish a piece that she has been struggling to complete. When her professor, Arthur Caban offers to send her to his cabin up in the Alps where she could potentially find inspiration, Wilma accepts and arrives to find herself surrounded by her fears, insecurities and pressure from both her peers and herself. 
The Lion’s Song first episode, titled Silence, is a wonderful piece of art about the pressure we allow others to put on us, the pressure we put on ourselves, our fears and how they can be interpreted of visualised, whether through dreams or the world that surrounds us, but it also is about patience and overcoming obstacles, big or small. In the first episode, you will be required to pay attention to Wilma’s pleas and fears, and help her find inspirations in the things that surrounds her and the sounds that will sometimes scare her, or inspire her, in order to complete her piece. 

The game allows you to learn various type of things about Wilma or the people in her life, different games will offer different types of information, and through some events, you can shape Wilma’s will, fears, and even the ending of the episode. 

Although the music is an important part of the game, a lot of it resides in the in-between, when you are searching inside of the cabin for something to spark Wilma’s attention and inspiration. Rain tapping against the window or a clock ticking, there is a surprising amount of objects for you to interact with, and the sounds, text and sometimes music that accompanies it are absolutely wonderful. 

I am extremely excited to see what Mi'pu'mi Games has in store for us, and to meet the other character that will be the protagonists of the next episodes. 

10/10 – I was pleasantly surprised to see that episode 1 was being given out for free, as I was more than ready to pay for it, but having experienced it now, I will most certainly be purchasing the season pass and wait for more wonderful storytelling. 

“Great games don’t have to be big” Absolutely.

24171195.review: In The Lion's Song, you play as a young but talented musical composer, Wilma. She struggles with a big piece, with no help from her professor Arthur, about whom she has confused feelings. Arthur sends her to his cabin in the Alps, where Wilma gradually finds inspiration in the elements all around her and composes her piece around them. While the play style is not innovative, the art style is pleasing to the eye and fitting to the type of game. It is a calming and interesting game overall. I look forward to the next episodes.

24170606.review:
I'm pleasantly surprised by the simplicity that is The Lion's Song.  As you can see by my time, as well as other reviewers'', the game is not exceptionally long.  Despite that, the brief hour you spend with the game will be delightful.  The Lion's Song boasts an impressive pixelated artstyle, a thoughtful score, and a nuanced story.

However, the game's enjoyment will be dependent on the player.  If you're not the type to really get invested in a character you may not enjoy the first playthrough that much.  Gameplay wise it's not very intricate, which might also put some people off.  Puzzles are almost non existant, save a few with very simple solutions.  The story can be a bit predictable as well.

That being said, I do recommend the first episode for anyone who thinks they'd be remotely interested in it.  It's free and truly worth taking slowly and reading all the dialogue.  There's a good chance I'll be replaying this game to get achievements and also see if the song at the end changes based on choices.

24170042.review:
I remember first hearing about Lion’s Song a few years back on RPS and I played the really early demo of Episode 1. It was neat enough, but I forgot about it until I saw its Steam page on the upcoming game list. Seeing is that the first episode was free I had no excuse not to play it.

Lion’s Song Episode 1 takes place in Vienna during the turn of the 20th century. You play as Wilma, a young woman that aspires to be a great violinist. She has the skills but she has recently fallen into a block. Her teacher, Arthur, (who she secretly has feelings for) sees it as pressure from the bustling city around her and offers Wilma to stay in his isolated cabin in the Alps by herself. Wilma agrees but at the cabin she learns that Arthur has planned a big concert with her in it and she has only a week to finish her new piece. As she begins to fret over this development she receives a phone call from a friendly Bohemian innkeeper named Leos who wanted to try out this newfangled phone he just got installed and is awed that he ended up calling someone hundreds of miles away. 

At this point it is up to the player to decide what to do. And that’s Lion’s Song’s gameplay, it’s a very streamlined point and click game where it focuses on how you have Wilma deal with her situation and her relationships with other people. Will you be determined to finish the composition, putting it above all else? Or will you take the time to just talk to Leos? Stuff like that. The game has really good atmosphere, the aesthetic is that of a sepia-toned photograph and it has a real nice soundtrack. It all really adds to the feeling of being alone in woods on a stormy night. The writing is good stuff too, I actually didn’t get to talk a lot to Leos out of my own choice and because of that the game became more of Wilma dealing with some soul searching on her own.

The only real major flaw I can say is that you can’t have multiple save files so I’d have to lose my progress if I wanted to replay and take a different path like spending more time talking to Leos but I don’t want to override my original choices. 

Overall Episode 1 is a real solid start and I’ll probably buy the whole season pass.  Also you got no excuse to not try it, it’s free.

At the end of the day it's a free game that killed some time and was kinda fun.

But I still don't know why it's called The lion's song

Dieses Spiel ist ein "Visual Novel". Kein Point and Click Adventure. Wer es nicht mag, eine stunde lang Texte weiter zu klicken und dabei mehr über die Psyche einer labilen Frau zu erfahren, der wird hier keinen Spaß finden.

Ich würde es begrüßen wenn der Entwickler dem Spiel noch den "Visual Novel" Stempel aufdrücken würde, so hätte ich eine Stunde meines Lebens sparen können (dachte bis zu letzt das dass eigentliche Spiel noch kommt)

I was drawn in by the art style, so when I saw the first episode was free I downloaded it straight away - and I'm so glad I did. Charming and well-written, The Lion's Song is a wonderful game! The point & click gameplay works well with the art style to immerse you into it's interesting story and character(s). I feel like the team have done a great job in making Ep1 relatable - even if you've never been an art student in love with your professor, we still all want something. We still need inspiration, and sometimes struggle with that. It really left me wanting more so I bought the Season Pass straight away!

Pros:
- Wonderful Art & Animation 
- Great use of music and audio cues (Amazing music, great emotion)
- Teaser Trailer at the end for Ep2!
- 'x% of players did this too' - Compare your choices with others
- Interactive credits (I've never seen this before, and it's awesome - well done!)

Cons: (They're not that important)
- Some broken English (Phrases that didn't make too much sense, missing words)
- Some of the art was too short for the frame (cut off legs etc)

Conclusion:
If you want to relax and enjoy something new, play this game. The team have created something pretty incredible so download it and give it a try.

24163844.review:
It's really hard not to recommend this game despite the severe lack of ''real interactivity'' and short length of the game.

This is indubitably an experience, and a short one at that. You wouldn't exactly call it a piece of art but neither can you call it pure trash.

𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐬 :
- Delightful art style, I really dig it.
- Player choices connect with the rest of the world, much of that in many Telltale Games series.
- Intriguing overall theme, deals with anxiety and friendship.
- Writing's good.
- Killer soundtrack.
- First episode's free. 

𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐎𝐡 𝐛𝐨𝐲, 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐞 𝐠𝐨) :
- Gameplay consists of picking from a short number of dialogue options, while clicking on a number of things that require no particular order, and while it IS heartwarming and cheerful to hear that fuzzy warm musical noise in the midst of the thunder and commotion, there's not much else, if nothing at all to it. That's all it is. A sound effect. Nothing more nothing less.
- Extremely short first episode for such a peculiar seeming title and first episode. Since it is the introduction, it gave me nothing to care about, I have no feelings towards any character but the heroine which I was most intrigued by. Her way of thinking mixed together with her other self is what makes her a truly brilliant protagonist.
- 10€ season pass. From the looks of it, and the ''In the next episode'' sequence at the ending it is switching the character every episode. I don't mind that at all because it keeps it fresh and full of surprises (maybe every new character is somehow linked to the previous's one story and it all blends well together), but I am also worried all in the same. The absurdly short length of this first (keep in mind, FREE of no charge) episode was barely enough to even spark my interest for a continuation. If the upcoming episodes are just as long, then it's not the game for me. Mostly because I'm not a MOVIES type of guy. Oh and also cause I'm not paying 10 fucking € for 2 hours worth of content.

𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐥𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 (𝐒𝐰𝐞𝐞𝐭 𝐛𝐮𝐭 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐫) :
Yes, I AM recommending it. It might not even be my kind of game but if I can find some form of enjoyment in it, which definitely did by the way, I think anyone can. The experience is mostly solid, short and sweet but by the end of it, it feels like things are missing and I can say that for every single game, as nothing ever is perfect. If you're looking to fill up 280MB or maybe look forward to wasting, (rephrase) enjoyably spending 40 minutes up to a full hour of your life then by all means, I'm not going to stop you.

Ein Spiel für alle, die mit einer etwas tiefgehenderen und ruhigen Story kein Problem haben - die zudem noch in Point & click Gameplay und Pixelgrafik verpackt ist. Von 2. halte ich für gewöhnlich nicht allzu viel, aber in dieses Spiel passt es außerordentlich gut, da hiermit der Retrocharakter des Spiels unterstrichen wird; die Geschichte spielt im alten Österreich.

Wir spielen eine junge Studentin, die eine für sie wohl eher ungesunde Liäison mit ihrem Uniprofessor angefangen hat, allerdings zur selben Zeit eine begnadete Komponistin ist. Ihr Talent und die Liebe zwingen Sie in eine unangenehme Lage, in der es an uns liegt, ihr den weiteren Weg zu weisen - bleiben wir in der Opferrolle, werden lediglich auf unser musikalisches Talent reduziert oder lehnen wir uns auf, werden ein selbstständiges Individuum?

Die erste Folge gibts hier kostenlos, und dafür kann man wirklich hiermit nichts falsch machen - mir hat das Spiel außerordentlich gut gefallen (bzw. weiterhin, da ich mir den Season Pass holen werde). Also, für die unter euch, die kein Problem mit Einfühlungsvermögen und gefühlvoller Protagonistin haben - zuschlagen!

Hier gäbe es noch einen kleinen Einblick von mir ins Spiel, für die, die es interessiert (allerdings eher ein wenig satirisch, also nichts zu ruhiges erwarten...):

39490999.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/obn4ga7]here[/url].

10/10

I was only supposed to be playing the last two episodes, but achievements dictated I replay the first two in a certain way. I’m glad I did, because I got to see the full story come together as one piece, moving as one, with an added bonus of a few patched touch-ups for the older chapters.

The result? Spectacular.

I had enjoyed the Lion’s Song back when I had just played the first chapter when it was first released for free - I liked it enough to immediately buy the season. I’m glad I did, because the investment is well worth it.

The Lion’s Song is a game set in Vienna, Austria about a year before the outbreak of WWI. You follow three people struggling with their work - a composer, a painter, and a mathematician - with major themes around self-expression, inspiration, and truth. It’s gorgeous. The music is beautiful. The writing is sicknasty.

On the steam forums for this game, somebody made a recent post asking whether the game was worth it, whether it was good. I replied, and I’ll quote myself here:

“I’m not a SUPER big crier, but I am pretty emotional - this game plucked at my heartstrings and I’ve choked up/cried some at least once each episode, sometimes multiple times per episode. The combination of the gorgeous, understated art style, the stunning soundtrack, and the way the text is presented in a ‘lively’ manner (it jitters and waves with the emotion of the person’s voice without losing readability) presents a seriously impactful game.

I’d rate it a ten out of ten and recommend it, period.”

Душевная и милая игра. Не требует каких-то особо трудных действий, разве что внимательности и терпение к чтению. Хорошая история, которая показывает, как ты можешь найти себе друга ответив на звонок чужого тебе человека и познакомится с ним.
Интересный жанр. Первый эпизод показался очень коротким, хочется поиграть в другие. Думаю, что потом поиграю и в них. 
<3

39596930.review: In just the first episode an amzing story is shown in an insanly atmospheric way. I have absolutely nothing bad to say about it and I already cant wait to play more.

39584449.review:
Невероятно глубокая, трогательная, эмоциональная вещь. Интересные и неизбитые самостоятельные сюжеты, гармонично складывающиеся в одну цельную картину. Игра на ~5 часов вызывает эмоций больше, чем некоторые на 20+. Помимо этого - великолепное музыкальное сопровождение, отличное повествование и необычная стилизация. Крайне душевно. 

Любителям хороших историй настоятельно рекомендуется к прохождению. Однако, имхо, лучше брать по скидке, ибо выходит дороговато.

Снимаю шляпу перед разработчиками, побольше бы таких творений.
